did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Connecticut State and New England Collection
did.abstract: The State of Connecticut and New England Collection offers contextualizing information for the study of the local history of Georgetown, Conn., by providing insight into the wider world in which Georgetown residents participated, through their involvement in activities and organizations in and their visits to Danbury, Bridgeport, New York City, and beyond.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: European exploration and colonization of Connecticut began with the Dutch in the early 1600s, and British settlers arrived soon after. The Connecticut Colony joined the Union as a state in 1788. Early historical connections between Connecticut and the surrounding colonies, and later states, were maintained overland via carriage routes and, where possible, using the rivers. Seaports, however, were the major focus of trade. The industrial revolution improved Connecticut's interstate connections with steamboats on the larger navigable rivers and with railroads, which began laying down track between 1839 and the 1850s and had grown extensively to cover the region by the end of the century. Telephones and later automobiles augmented these earlier trends and brought them into the home by the early twentieth century, further facilitating the local and regional connections and activities of Georgetown residents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Notable items in the Connecticut State and New England Collection include an illustrated booklet of Danbury and northern Fairfield County in the wake of the 1955 flood; documents from the Norwalk River Watershed Association regarding its Norwalk River Mill Project; miscellaneous papers relating to businesses, clubs, cultural events, schools, and churches, primarily in Danbury, Norwalk, and New York; items relating to politics and government in Connecticut; postcards; pamphlets for Connecticut utilities; a booklet of Connecticut traffic rules; a collection of Connecticut postmarks; and miscellaneous ephemera and realia. The collection also contains a many photographs, primarily carte-de-visite portraiture.
